Yes, Apple has faced issues related to the responsible sourcing of minerals in the past. In 2010, an organization called the Enough Project released a report that linked some of the minerals used in Apple's products to human rights abuses in the Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC). Specifically, the report alleged that armed groups in the region were profiting from the mining of minerals like tantalum, tungsten, and tin. These minerals were then sold to smelters, and some of these smelters were believed to be supplying Apple.

Following the release of the report, Apple took several steps to address these issues. Some of these steps include:

1. Improving supplier auditing processes: Apple expanded its auditing processes to more mines, smelters, and refiners to determine the origin of minerals.

2. Partnering with industry groups: Apple joined with the Electronic Industry Citizenship Coalition (EICC) and Global e-Sustainability Initiative (GeSI) to promote conflict-free minerals in the supply chain.

3. Conducting more audits: Later, Apple began "Special Project" audits in which they visited the sources of various minerals to investigate conditions and form action plans.

4. Developing a Conflict Minerals Report: In 2014, Apple released a report detailing the measures it had taken to ensure that the minerals used in its products were sourced responsibly.

5. Conducting research: Apple conducted its own research and investigations on mining practices and needs, publishing its own report of independent research from two NGOs in the Democratic Republic of Congo, Rwanda, and Burundi.

Today, Apple maintains a commitment to responsible sourcing and continues to work towards improving the ethical standards within its supply chain.
